Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket as I haul a heavy plank across the site, sweat trickling down my back. I know it’s probably Mom or Dad, just checking in like they always do on weekends. I haven’t replied to their last message yet, and I can almost hear Mom’s gentle voice in my head, “Just let us know you’re okay, sweetheart.” But the carpenter is waving at me, impatience clear on his face. He needs the next load of lumber now, and if I slow down, the whole crew will be waiting. My hands are rough and splintered, and I can’t just drop everything to text. But if I don’t answer soon, my parents will worry, maybe even call. I feel torn, the weight of the lumber matched only by the guilt pressing on my chest. I want to be a good daughter, to reassure them, but right now, I’m needed here, and the work won’t wait. My phone buzzes again, and I freeze, caught between two worlds, not sure which one to let down.
